title: Sudden Dizziness When Standing Up
description: Sudden dizziness when standing up is often a brief feeling of light-headedness, spinning, or unsteadiness that happens as you rise from sitting or lying down. It usually lasts a few seconds to a minute.

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
Orthostatic Hypotension: A sudden drop in blood pressure when standing up. Common in dehydration, prolonged sitting, or certain medications.

Dehydration: Not drinking enough water can reduce blood volume, causing dizziness.

Anemia: Low red blood cell count means less oxygen to the brain.

Low blood sugar: Especially if you haven’t eaten for a while or have diabetes.

Inner ear problems (like vertigo): Affects balance and may cause spinning or swaying sensations.

Medication side effects: Some drugs for blood pressure, depression, or anxiety can cause dizziness.

Heart problems: Irregular heartbeat or poor circulation can trigger dizzy spells.

Fatigue or lack of sleep: Can reduce alertness and blood pressure.

sections.heading: Symptoms to Watch For
sections.content:
Light-headedness or “head rush”

Feeling faint or off balance

Blurry vision

Nausea

Weakness or shakiness

Tinnitus (ringing in ears)

Shortness of breath or chest discomfort (if heart-related)

sections.heading: What to Do Immediately
sections.content:
Sit or lie down right away to avoid falling.

Take deep breaths slowly.

Raise your legs if lying down — it helps blood flow back to the brain.

Drink water if you haven’t had fluids in a while.

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor or Go to the ER
sections.content:
Dizziness happens frequently or severely

You faint or lose consciousness

It’s accompanied by chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath

You feel confused or weak on one side of the body

You have vision or speech problems

You’re on blood pressure medication and the symptoms are new or worsening

sections.heading: Home Care and Lifestyle Tips
sections.content:
Get up slowly from bed or chair — pause between sitting and standing.

Drink plenty of fluids — especially in hot weather or after exercise.

Eat regular meals — avoid skipping meals to prevent low blood sugar.

Wear compression socks (if advised) to improve blood circulation.

Avoid alcohol — it can lower blood pressure.

Monitor medications — talk to your doctor if you suspect a side effect.

sections.heading: Emergency Medicines (only if prescribed)
sections.content:
Fludrocortisone – Raises blood pressure in cases of orthostatic hypotension.

Midodrine – Used for chronic low blood pressure.

Meclizine – For dizziness caused by inner ear issues.

Glucose tablets or snacks – If low blood sugar is the cause.

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t stand up too fast.

Don’t ignore frequent episodes — it could be a sign of something serious.

Don’t skip meals or stay dehydrated.

Don’t drive or operate machines during an episode.
